messages.subject: Re: [nihonto] Hazama Tsuba & Kunitomo
messages.msgSnippet: Most (if not all?) signed Kunitomo tsuba I have seen have been iron. I think I have only seen two tsuba (maybe 3?) signed Hazama that were in iron. Nearly all
messages.messageBody:
Most (if not all?) signed Kunitomo tsuba I have seen
have been iron. I think I have only seen two tsuba
(maybe 3?) signed Hazama that were in iron. Nearly all
the Hazama tsuba I have seen have been copper of some
form, including one with very high grade shakudo
inlaid to image open fans.

I have seen disproportionately more tsuba signed
Hazama than signed Kunitomo tsuba, but wouldn't hang
any sort of statistical correlation on it yet.

Curran





--- Alan Bale <abale@...> wrote:

> I think most Hazama tsuba are iron as are Kunitomo,
> soft metal plate or inlay are rare.
> Alan
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: Curran Campbell
> To: nihonto@yahoogroups.com ;
> nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: Saturday, May 05, 2007 4:26 PM
> Subject: [nihonto] Hazama Tsuba & Kunitomo
>
>
> Lists,
>
> I've been studying 2 Kunitomo & 2 Hazama tsuba
> recently. Having read the Koza entry, Haynes
> Index,
> Torigoye, and a few other references- there seems
> to
> be a lot of confusion.
>
> Haynes Index indicates the relationship between
> the
> Kunitomo tsuba vs those signed Hazama is unclear.
> The
> Koza has the founder being Kunitomo Mura <?> (no
> clarification or mention of whether he ever
> signed)
> and then Kunitomo Teihei (aka Sadashige) moving to
> Kameyama and working.
>
> Some texts state the Hazama came first, then the
> Kunitomo. Other seem to have it the other way
> around.
> Anyone able to share the current thought on these
> groups. Are they one and the same, or two doing
> similar work?
> What is the standing and relation of Teiei
> (Sadashige) to those signed Hazama? Should he be
> considered the founder of a Kameyama subgroup of
> the
> Kunitomo? His work seems the most primitive of the
> 4
> tsuba, but then he and the other Kunitomo tsuba
> are
> working in iron while the Hazama are in much
> softer
> copper.
>
> Any help much appreciated!
>
> Curran
>
>
>
